title.narrative: Integra–Initiative to Guarantee Rights of Stateless Persons

description.narrative: The activities will work towards: 1) Stateless residents of the Dominican Republic, including those of Haitian ancestry, are educated on their right to nationality and the process of obtaining nationality documents; 2) Haitian migrant women are educated on prevention of statelessness of their children; 3) Haitian descent/ migrant women obtain birth certificates and other documentation, and are empowered to seek nationality for themselves and their children; 4) Children are prevented from being stateless; 5) Local partner organization’s capacities of providing legal assistance to stateless persons are strengthened; 6) Local partner organizations’ capacity for program and financial management is strengthened and accountability is enhanced; 7) An estimate of the stateless population is measured in the project areas of intervention and specific related data gathered (type of statelessness, age, civil status etc.); 8) Key stakeholders sensitized in order on statelessness persons’ status.

The goal of this project is to reduce statelessness in marginalized neighbourhoods of West Santo Domingo by educating the target population on their rights and providing them with essential, understandable and accurate information on the current laws and procedures related to nationality documentation. The complex mosaic of laws creates both opportunities and risks for Haitian-Dominicans depending on date of birth, existence of birth records, the date and circumstances of ancestor arrival in the Dominican Republic, and other factors. HAI and MUDHA will educate communities on their rights and on current law. Direct legal and documentation assistance will be provided using a participant-centered approach, in which individuals will be fully educated on risks and benefits, and empowered to make decisions about whether or not to seek documentation and nationality. Nobody will be pressured or otherwise encouraged to obtain nationality. The project will serve Haitian-Dominicans of all ages and genders, but will particularly focus on women of Haitian descent with children born after 2010, or those who are likely to have children, in order to prevent statelessness for children who are unambiguously eligible for nationality under existing law. Through sensitizing and supporting the target population to exercise their right to nationality, specific data will be also be gathered to measure the presence of stateless persons in the communities of intervention.
